Fig. 6 Pore size-dependent confinement: High selectivity promoted by pore-confined Au single-atom catalysts in direct arylation Jianing Zhang Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Resources Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization Xuebing Ma Writing – original draft Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southwest University, Chongqing 400715, PR China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southwest University Chongqing 400715 PR China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southwest University, Chongqing, 400715, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. The Au-promoted direct arylation of simple arenes (Ar1-H) with arylsilanes (Ar2-SiMe3) to construct widely used biaryls (Ar1-Ar2) in high selectivities has an undoubted synthetic value but remains challenging. Herein, the direct covalent immobilization of Ph3PAuOAc to crosslinker-pillared hollow porous polystyrene nanospheres is developed via AlCl3-promoted Scholl reaction, affording supported Au catalysts with the fascinating structural features including nanosphere, hollow interior, pore-abundant shell with tunable pore size, and atomically dispersed Au. Fast mass transfer of reactant, pore size-depending selectivity, and highly active Au single-atom enable direct arylation to achieve high conversions (> 96.1 %) of 4-FC6H4SiMe3 with excellent selectivities (> 96.7 %) of hetero-coupling biphenyls, whereas homogeneous Au catalysts show unsatisfactory conversions with poor selectivities (< 49.8 %). The Au catalyst has a good reusability with a record turnover number (TON = 1.18 × 105) over twelve recycles. Overall, this paper showcases a success in achieving highly selective synthesis of biaryls originating from pore-dependent confinement. Most common and versatile method for the construction of biaryls is widely appreciated by the transition metal–catalyzed hetero-coupling of an aryl halide (Ar1-X) with an aryl organometallic (Ar2-M) [3,4]. Driven by a need for more concise, selective, and green synthesis of biaryls, many efforts have been devoted to direct arylation in which Ar1-X is replaced by a simple arene (Ar1-H) [5–10]. Nevertheless, the inherent low reactivity of C-H bond and regioselectivity for a specific C-H bond in Ar1–H is desirable to be solved. Actually, many of these extant methodologies involve harsh conditions, limitation of substrate scope, and high loadings of metal catalyst. Fortunately, the gold-catalyzed oxidative hetero-coupling of arenes (Ar1-H) with arylsilanes (Ar2-SiMe3) to construct biaryls is especially prized, due to its remarkably mild conditions, low loadings, and tolerance of functionalities [11]. However, the desired oxidative hetero-coupling of Ar1-H with Ar2-SiMe3 is inevitably accompanied by the homo-coupling (Ar2-Ar2) of Ar2-SiMe3, electrophilic substitution (Ar1-Ar1) of Ar1–H, and further hetero-coupling (Ar2-Ar1-Ar2) of Ar1-Ar2 with Ar2-SiMe3. Furthermore, the regioselective hetero-coupling of substituted Ar1-H with Ar2-SiMe3 can occur at the o, p-positions of substituted Ar1-H. These side reactions lead to a significant decrease in the selectivities of desired biaryls (Ar1-Ar2). Moreover, the high usage of expensive Au catalysts enables the oxidative hetero-coupling to proceed under a high price level, limiting its broad applications from an economic point of view. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop a simple, convenient, and effective strategy for avoiding the side reactions including homo-coupling of Ar2-SiMe3 and low-selective hetero-coupling of Ar1-H with Ar2-SiMe3 to improve the selectivities of desired biaryls. Herein, inspired by high selectivity and activity of enzyme with a well-confined space around active site [12,13] and pore confinement in heterogeneous catalysis [14–18], Ph3PAuOAc is covalently anchored in a direct and convenient way to the tailored pores of linker-pillared hollow microporous/mesoporous polystyrene nanospheres via AlCl3-promoted Scholl reaction. The as-fabricated Au single-atom-site catalysts possess the fascinating structural and morphological features including nanosphere, hollow cavity, porous shell with a tunable pore size, and atomically dispersed Au, which are suitable for achieving high conversions of reactants and excellent selectivities of Ar1-Ar2. In comparison with homogeneous Au catalysts, the supported Au single-atom catalysts exhibit high conversions (>96.1 %) of 4-FC6H4SiMe3 with excellent selectivities (>96.7 %) for hetero-coupling Ar1-Ar2 in the direct arylation of Ar1-H (benzene, toluene, and o-xylene) with Ar2-SiMe3 (FC6H4SiMe3), due to pore-dependent confinement and Au single-atom. Moreover, the Au single-atoms, anchored to the confined pores, show good chemical and mechanical stabilities including morphology, porous structure, and Au single-atom over the twelve recycles with a record turnover number (TON = 1.18 × 105). 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and characterization Styrene (St) was purified by distillation under reduced pressure before use. The other reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Solid-state 13C CP/MAS NMR spectra were recorded on a Agilent 600 DD2 spectrometer (Agilent, USA, magnetic field strength 14.1 T) at a resonance frequency of 150.7 MHz for 13C using the cross-polarization (CP), magic-angle spinning (MAS), and a high-power 1H decoupling. The powder samples were placed in a pencil-type zirconia rotor of 4.0 mm o.d. The spectra were obtained at a spinning speed of 10 kHz (4.2 μs 90° pulses), a 2 ms CP pulse, and a recycle delay of 3 s. Elemental analysis was obtained using a vario Micro cube elemental analyzer. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analysis was performed with an Agilent 720ES instrument to detect the contents of Au and P. GC and GC-MS analyses were performed on a Varian 3900 GC (column: Varian FactorFOUR capillary column, VF-1MS 25 m × 0.25 mm, ID = 0.25 μm) and a Varian Saturn 2100 T MS (EI+) (1 mL min−1; 80 °C, 2 min; 80→250 °C, 17 min, 10 °C min−1; 250 °C, 2 min). Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained with a ZEISS Gemini 300 operating at 10.0–30.0 kV, where samples were coated with a thin layer of gold before testing. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was conducted on a FEI Talos F200S operated at 200 kV. Aberration-corrected transmission electron microscopic (AC-TEM) images were performed on a JEM-2100 with accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi with Al Kα irradiation at θ = 90° for X-ray sources, and the spectrometer binding energy was calibrated through the reference C1s (284.9 eV). The samples were pressed to a tablet and pasted on the sample stage using conducting resin, and the pressure of the vacuum chamber was lower than 10−10 mbar when testing while a step size of 0.10 eV was employed. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured on Autosorb IQ at 77.35 K, and kinetic sorption curves of PhH, PhCH3 and o-xylene were measured at 298 K on Quadrasorb Aquadyne DVS. Before measurement, the samples were outgassed in a vacuum at 125 °C for 12 h. The surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett- Teller (BET) method using the adsorption data in a relative pressure (P/P 0) range from 0.005 to 0.25. The pore size distribution was calculated by using the quenched solid density functional theory (QSDFT) method, and the total pore volume (V m) was estimated from the adsorbed amount at the relative pressure (P/P 0) of 0.990. Au L 3-edge XAFS analysis was performed with Si(111) crystal monochromators at the BL14W Beam line at the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF) (Shanghai, China). Before the analysis at the beamline, samples were placed into aluminum sample holders and sealed using Kapton tape film. The XAFS spectra were recorded at room temperature using a 4-channel Silicon Drift Detetor (SDD) Bruker 5040. Au L 3-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra were recorded in transmission mode. Negligible changes in the line-shape and peak position of Au L 3-edge XANES spectra were observed between two scans taken for a specific sample. The XAFS spectra of these standard samples were recorded in transmission mode. The spectra were processed and analyzed by the software codes Athena. 2.2 Synthesis of supports with different pore sizes After the well-shaped pre-polymer of hollow microporous polymeric nanosheres (pre -HMiPNs, 0.3 g) was dispersed in 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE, 30 mL) at 25 °C for 12 h, the cross-linker 1,3,5-tribromobenzene (TBB, 0.94 g, 3.0 mmol) and anhydrous AlCl3 (0.40 g, 3.0 mmol) were added, stirred at 45 °C for 12 h, heated to 80 °C for 24 h, and then quenched with EtOH (10 mL). The isolated solids by centrifugal separation were washed by deionized water (20 mL), THF (40 mL × 3) and ethanol (30 mL × 3), and dried naturally to afford TBB-pillared hollow microporous polystyrene nanospheres [HMiPNs(TBB), 0.34 g]. According the same procedure as HMiPNs(TBB), 1,3,5-tri(4-bromophenyl)benzene (TBPB) and 4,4⁗-dibromo-5″-(4′-bromo-[1,1'-biphenyl]−4-yl)−1,1′:4′,1″:3″,1‴:4‴,1⁗-quinquephenyl (TBPBext)-pillared hollow mesoporous polystyrene nanospheres, abbreviated as HMePNs(TBPB) (0.48 g) and HMePNs(TBPBext) (0.53 g), were obtained by replacing TBB with TBPB and TBPBext, respectively. Moreover, hollow microporous polystyrene nanospheres (HMiPNs, 0.27 g) were also obtained via Scholl reaction of the phenyls attached to pre -HMiPNs in the absence of cross-linker according to the same procedure as HMiPNs(TBB). 2.3 Preparation of supported Au catalysts The supports, HMiPNs, HMiPNs(TBB), HMePNs(TBPB), and HMePNs(TBPBext) (0.20 g), were well-dispersed in DCE (30 mL) at 25 °C for 12 h, PPh3AuOAc (1.04 g, 2.0 mmol) and anhydrous AlCl3 (1.33 g, 10.0 mmol) were added, and stirred at 80 °C for 24 h. The isolated solids by centrifugal separation were washed with THF (40 mL × 3) and CHCl3 (30 mL × 3), and naturally dried in air to afford supported Au catalysts, hereafter denoted as Au@HMiPNs (0.39 g), Au@HMiPNs(TBB) (0.41 g), Au@HMePNs(TBPB) (0.47 g), and Au@HMePNs(TBPBext) (0.49 g), respectively. The loading capacities of Au in Au@HMiPNs, Au@HMiPNs(TBB), Au@HMePNs(TBPB), and Au@HMePNs(TBPBext) are determined by ICP-OES to be 0.11, 0.59, 0.88, and 0.70 mmol g−1, respectively. 2.4 General direct arylation 4-FC6H4SiMe3 (168.3 mg, 1.0 mmol), arene (1.0 mmol), and a mixed solvents of CHCl3 (5 mL) and MeOH (0.1 mL) were added to a vial (10 mL) containing supported Au catalyst (0.1 mol% of Au). After being well-dispersed, PhI(OAc)2 (483.1 mg, 1.5 mmol) and camphorsulfonic acid (CSA, 348.4 mg, 1.5 mmol) were added and stirred at 25 °C for 15 h. The products in the resulting reaction mixture were confirmed by GC-MS using standard samples and quantitatively determined by GC. In this reaction, the turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF) of Au catalyst in each cycle is calculated, according to the following equations: TON = amount of product (mmol)/used Au catalyst (mmol); TOF = TON/reaction time (h). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Construction of pores with different apertures Compared with traditional porous materials such as zeolites and activated carbon, porous organic polymer networks via a direct knitting strategy, including polymers of intrinsic microporosity (PIMs), hypercrosslinked polymers (HCPs), conjugated microporous polymers (CMPs), and porous aromatic frameworks (PAFs), exhibit the indispensable advantages of high porosity, good tolerant of severe environments and easy functionalization for broad applications [19–22]. However, there are two issues requiring urgent improvements: (i) the exquisite synthesis of functional monomers for fabricating porous structure, (ii) well-shaped morphology with an adjustable aperture suitable for mass transfer and shape-selective catalysis. Herein, using TBB, TBPB, and TBPBext as cross-linkers and hollow microporous polymeric nanospheres (Fig.S1 and Fig.S2) as a prepolymer (Pre -HMiPNs), the well-shaped hollow microporous/mesoporous polymeric nanospheres ( Fig. 1b) with uniform particle sizes (Fig.S3), high porosities (Fig. 1c) and uniform pore sizes (Fig. 1d), namely HMiPNs(TBB), HMePNs(TBPB) and HMePNs(TBPBext), are prepared by the pillarings of TBB, TBPB, and TBPBext via AlCl3-promoted Scholl reaction between the phenyls of cross-linkers and pre -HMiPNs (Fig. 1a). It's worth mentioning that the attempt to fabricate well-shaped and pore-abundant HMePNs(TBPB) instead of TBPB with available 1,3,5-triphenylbenzene (TPB) as a cross-linker is unsuccessful, due to the fast side self-coupling of TPB to afford microporous polymers (SMPs) with an irregular morphology (Fig.S4) [23]. In the preparation of HMiPNs(TBB), HMePNs(TBPB) and HMePNs(TBPBext), the Scholl-couplings of TBB, TBPB and TBPBext with the phenyls in Pre -HMiPNs at 80 °C proceed through two steps: debromination and coupling via dehydrogenation under Scholl reaction [24–26]. The debromination of TBPB in the Scholl-coupling is verified by the XPS spectrum of SMPs obtained by dealing TBPB with AlCl3 in DCE at 80 °C. In comparison with the XPS spectrum of TBPB, the atomic percent of bromine in the SMPs decreases from 8.9 % to 1.2 % (Fig.S5a). Furthermore, the enhanced 13C resonance signals (128–148 ppm) in solid-state CP/MAS 13C NMR confirm that TBPB is embedded in the framework of HMePNs(TBPB) to pillar the flexible polystyrene chains in the shell (Fig. 1e). From the SEM images (Fig. 1b), all samples possess a well-shaped morphology of nanospheres with the particle size distributions in the ranges of 150250 nm centered at about 195 nm (Fig.S3). From N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm (Fig.S2), pre -HMiPNs possesses a relatively low surface area (125.3 m2 g−1) due to the accumulation of flexible polystyrene. After the chains of polystyrene in the shell of pre -HMiPNs are directly connected among the phenyls in polystyrene chains via the AlCl3-promoted coupling, the obtained HMiPNs show an increase in surface area (427.5 m2 g−1). When the shell of pre -HMiPNs is pillared by TBB, HMiPNs(TBB) can adsorb more N2 (Fig. 1c) and shows a significantly increased surface area (1602.8 m2 g−1) and a pore volume (1.33 cc g−1) with a uniform pore size distribution centered at 0.93 nm (Fig. 1d). Further increasing the volume of cross-linker, both HMePNs(TBPB) and HMePNs(TBPBext) show the typical N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of Type IVa given by mesoporous adsorbents (Fig. 1c) [27], indicating that they possess abundant mesopores in their shells. Owing to the bulkier volume of TBPBext than TBPB, TBPBext-pillared HMePNs(TBPBext) has the larger pore size centered at 5.76 nm than TBPB-pillared HMePNs(TBPB) with pore sizes centered at 3.43 nm and 4.52 nm (Fig. 1d). However, HMePNs(TBPB) exhibits the significantly higher surface area (2064.8 m2 g−1) and pore volume (2.23 cc g−1) than HMePNs(TBPBext) (1462.7 m2 g−1 and 0.45 cc g−1) (Table S1). Based on cylindrical pore model, all the fitted lines show very low fitting errors below 0.5 % (Fig.S7), indicating that the shapes of the pores in HMiPNs(TBB), HMePNs(TBPB) and HMePNs(TBPBext) tend to be more cylindrical [28]. 3.2 Direct immobilization of PPh3AuOAc Direct immobilization of expensive homogeneous catalysts without fussy molecular modification to solid supports in green manner at low-cost is highly admirable for fabricating supported catalysts [29–36]. Herein, the direct anchoring of PPh3AuOAc to well-shaped supports, including HMiPNs, HMiPNs(TBB), HMePNs(TBPB) and HMePNs(TBPBext), is developed to fabricate supported Au catalysts via AlCl3-promoted Scholl reaction between the phenyls of PPh3AuOAc and supports ( Fig. 2a). The binding energies of P 2p (131.7 eV) (Fig.S12), Au 4f5/2 centered in the range of 87.988.4 and 4 f7/2 centered in the range of 84.284.7 (Fig. 2h), 13C resonance signal of the carbonyl in OAc (208.8 ppm), and 31P resonance signal of PPh3 (27.1 ppm) (Fig. 2e) ensure the successful immobilization of PPh3AuOAc. The loading capacities of PPh3AuOAc, monitored by ICP-OES, are closely related to the surface areas, pore volumes and pore sizes of the supports (Fig. 2b). Owing to the narrowest pore size (0.70 nm) of HMiPNs with a lowest surface area (427.5 m2 g−1) and a pore volume (0.17 cc g−1), the loading of PPh3AuOAc in HMiPNs is significantly lower than other supports. HMePNs(TBPB) with a highest surface area and pore volume shows a continual anchoring of PPh3AuOAc during 12 h. The largest pore size enables HMePNs(TBPBext) to anchor PPh3AuOAc in a fastest rate within the first two hours and to quickly reach the saturation. The loading capacities of Au in Au@HMiPNs, Au@HMiPNs(TBB), Au@HMePNs(TBPB), and Au@HMePNs(TBPBext) are determined by ICP-OES to be 0.11, 0.59, 0.88, and 0.70 mmol g−1, respectively. From the SEM images (Fig. 2c and Fig.S13315), TEM images, and TEM-EDS mappings (Fig. 2d and Fig.S16318), all supported Au catalysts retain the original well-shaped morphology of hollow polymeric nanospheres. Owing to the pillaring of anchored PPh3AuOAc, the increased particle sizes are observed for all supported Au catalysts (Fig.S10). From N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 2f), all the supported Au catalysts exhibit the similar curves as their parent supports but the decreases in the volumes of adsorbed N2. Because the anchored PPh3AuOAc occupies some free spaces, the surface areas and pore volumes of Au@HMiPNs, Au@HMiPNs(TBB), Au@HMePNs(TBPB), and Au@HMePNs(TBPBext) are reduced to 322.1 m2 g−1 and 0.45 cc g−1, 1068.4 m2 g−1 and 0.94 cc g−1, 1221.1 m2 g−1 and 1.32 cc g−1, and 1028.3 m2 g−1 and 1.04 cc g−1, respectively. In the meantime, some smaller micropores and mesopores are newly emerged (Fig. 2g). Based on cylindrical pores model [28], the supported Au catalysts still possess cylindrical pores with very low fitting errors (< 0.4 %) (Fig.S9). 3.3 Anchored Au single-atoms From the high-angle annular dark field-scanning TEM (AC HAADF-STEM) image of Au@HMiPNs (Fig.S18), it is observed that the anchored PPh3AuOAc is presented as bright spots and mainly distributed on the surface in an aggregate state, due to the blockage of the narrow pores in HMiPNs on PPh3AuOAc. The other supports with larger pore sizes, including HMiPNs(TBB), HMePNs(TBPB), and HMePNs(TBPBext), can provide rooms large enough to accommodate PPh3AuOAc, enabling PPh3AuOAc to be uniformly anchored to the confined pores in the shells. The aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark field-scanning TEM (AC HAADF-STEM) images ( Fig. 3a) and enlarged AC HAADF-STEM image of Au@HMePNs(TBPB) with corresponding 3D heightmap (Fig. 3b) show that the bright spots of Au atoms are isolated and well-dispersed, indicating PPh3AuOAc is anchored as single-atom rather than nanocluster or nanoparticle. The similar Au single-atom in HMiPNs(TBB) (Fig.S19) and HMePNs(TBPBext) (Fig.S20) are also observed from their AC HAADF-STEM images. To further confirm the chemical state of the Au single-atom, synchrotron-radiation-based extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) are performed using Au@HMePNs(TBPB) as an example. Fourier transform (FT)-EXAFS curve of Au@HMePNs(TBPB) at the Au L3-edge shows a main peak at 1.6 Å with no peak assigned to Au–Au coordination of Au foil (>2.0 Å) (Fig. 3e). From the wavelet transform (WT) contour map of Au foil, it can be analyzed that the highest intensity maximum at 2.7 Å in R-space and 9.5 Å−1 in k-space corresponds to the Au−Au coordination. However, the WT spectrum of Au@HMePNs(TBPB) detects a peak intensity maximum at 1.5 Å in R-space and 6.6 Å−1 in k-space (Fig. 3d), which is referred to as Au−O coordination in PPh3AuOAc [37,38]. Based on the above results of XANES and AC HAADFSTEM, it is further confirmed that PPh3AuOAc is covalently anchored to Au@HMePNs(TBPB) in the form of Au single-atom. Moreover, compared to the XANES spectrum of Au foil, Au@HMePNs(TBPB) shows a sharp peak at 11,925 eV (Fig. 3c), arising from the electronic transition of Au 2p3/2 to unoccupied 5d or 6 s states. The binding energy of Au@HMePNs(TBPB) is lower than that of Au foil, indicating the Au species in Au@HMePNs(TBPB) are positively charged [38]. It can be seen from EXAFS fitting at 1.6 Å in R-space (Fig. 3f) and quantitative structural parameters (Table S2) that the coordination number of the anchored Au single-atom in Au@HMePNs(TBPB) is about 2, indicating that the coordination state of anchored PPh3AuOAc remains unchanged in comparison with PPh3AuOAc. 3.4 Pore-dependent conversion It is known that single-atom-site catalysis [39–42] and hollow nanospheres [32–34, 43–51] as supports are effective strategies for significantly improving catalytic activity of heterogeneous catalyst, due to the high dispersity of catalytic sites and the fast mass transfer of reactants. In the arylations of benzene, toluene, and o-xylene with 4-FC6H4SiMe3, there are three experimental results deserving particular attentions. First, Au@HMePNs(TBPB) (0.1 mol% of used Au) show the significantly higher conversions of 4-FC6H4SiMe3 than other Au catalysts in the direct arylations of benzene (98.7 %), toluene (96.1 %) and o-xylene (>99.5 %) (15 h). Upon increasing Au loading to 1.10 mol%, the conversion is reduced to 92.3 %, due to the partial aggregation of PPh3AuOAc (table S3, entry 15). These higher conversions mainly depend on the single-atom of anchored PPh3AuOAc and the highest uptakes of benzene ( Fig. 4d), toluene (Fig. 4e), and o-xylene (Fig. 4f), due to the mesopore sizes (3.43 and 4.52 nm), high surface area (1221.1 m2 g−1) and large pore volume (1.32 cc g−1) of Au@HMePNs(TBPB). Second, homogeneous PPh3OAc (1.0 mol% of Au) shows a lowest conversions (57.9 %) in the direct arylation of benzene with a small volume (Fig. 4a), which is possibly related to the agglomeration of PPh3OAc in the mixed solvents of CHCl3 and MeOH. As the volume of Ar1-H increases, Au@HMiPNs promotes the arylation of toluene in a lower conversion (24.4 %) than homogeneous PPh3OAc (40.9 %) (Fig. 4b). This phenomenon is also observed for Au@HMiPNs(TBB) with a conversion of 56.9 % in the arylation with bulky o-xylene (Fig. 4c). These lower conversions than homogeneous PPh3OAc are attributed to the blocking of the micropores in Au@HMiPNs and Au@HMiPNs(TBB) for bulkier toluene and o-xylene. Moreover, it is found that the space matching of the pores and the reactants plays an important role in the conversions of 4-FC6H4SiMe3. Au@HMiPNs(TBB) and Au@HMiPNs with narrow micropores have the very low uptakes of o-xylene (Fig. 4f), leading to the low conversions in the arylation with bulky o-xylene. Only Au@HMePNs(TBPB) and Au@HMePNs(TBPBext) with larger pore sizes can achieve the excellent conversions (>99.5 %) of 4-FC6H4SiMe3 (Fig. 4c). 3.5 High chemoselectivity The current Au-promoted direct arylation involves the major defects including a large deviation from stoichiometry for achieving moderate chemoselectivity, side homocoupling of Ar2-SiMe3, and further heterocoupling of Ar1-Ar2 with Ar2-SiMe3, which leads to the low chemoselectivities of Ar1-Ar2. In the direct arylation of benzene with 4-FC6H4SiMe3 promoted by various Au catalysts (15 h), the data, including the selectivities of 4-flurobiphenyl (1a), 4,4´-diflurobiphenyl (DFBP), and 4,4´-di(4-flurophenyl)phenyl (1b), TON and TOF, are shown in Fig. 5a and listed in Table S3. At the 1:1 stoichiometry of benzene and 4-FC6H4SiMe3 and 1.0 mol% of Au, homogeneous PPh3AuOAc produces the desired 1a via heterocoupling in the chemoselectivity of only 11.0 % (TON/TOF = 6/0.4 h−1), accompanied by DFBP in 48.5 % and 1b in 40.5 %. The similar low chemoselectivities of 1a in 13.529.6 %, DFBP in 35.456.5 %, and 1b in 30.035.0 % are also observed for PPh3AuCl and PPh3AuOTs (Table S3). Even the reaction time is prolonged to 36 h, only 34 % yield of 1a is obtained in the previous literature [11]. Under the same conditions, all supported Au catalysts exhibit higher catalytic performances (TON/TOF = 267958/17.863.6 h−1) including conversion and selectivity than homogeneous Au catalysts (Fig.S23326) within 15 h. Among them, Au@HMePNs(TBPB) shows a highest conversion (>99 %) with an excellent selectivity (95.8 %) (Fig.S24). When the usage of Au is reduced to 0.1 mol%, it is found that all homogeneous Au catalysts show very low conversions (<5 %). Fortunately, there is no significant decrease in conversion for all supported Au catalysts. Among them, Au@HMiPNs(TBB) and Au@HMePNs(TBPB) can maintain the high chemoselectivities of 1a in 95.9 % and 94.7% together with 1b in 4.1 % and 5.1 %, respectively. Meanwhile, the chemoselectivities for the undesired DFBP and 1b are also effectively suppressed. Unfortunately, the chemoselectivities for 1a are significantly reduced to 59.2 % for Au@HMePNs(TBPBext) with a largest pore size (5.72 nm) and 41.5 % for Au@HMiPNs with a narrowest pore size (0.85 nm). It's worth noting that the partial aggregation of Au on the surface of Au@HMePNs(TBPB) with 1.10 mol% of Au loading leads to a littile decrease in the chemoselectivity for the desired 1a from 96.7 % to 90.1 % at the same usage of Au (0.1 mol%). These results indicate that the high chemoselectivity of the desired 1a can be achieved by anchoring a suitable amount of PPh3AuOAc to the porous framework of solid support with a suitable pore size. Based on the catalytic mechanism of homogeneous Au(I)-promoted direct arylation of arenes with aryltrimethylsilanes [52–57], the overall catalytic cycle to afford the products including 1a, DFBP and 1b in heterogeneous Au-catalyzed arylation of benzene with 4-FC6H4SiMe3 is proposed (Fig. 5b). Owing to the lack of steric limitation in homogeneous catalysis, all the homogeneous Au catalysts can competitively activate the reactants to afford the various intermediates (1 V, V DFBP , and 1 V´) according to their own reactivities, which leads to the very low chemoselectivity (11.029.6 %) for the desired 1a (Table S3). Nevertheless, the formations of these intermediates suffer from the constriction imposed by the confined space in porous materials. Among the three intermediates, the intermediates V DFBP and 1 V´ require relatively larger free spaces than the intermediate 1 V, due to the bulkier volumes of 4-FC6H4SiMe3 and 1a than that of benzene. Au@HMiPNs(TBB) with the pores centered at 0.93 nm and Au@HMePNs(TBPB) with the pores centered at 3.43 nm and 4.52 nm cannot provide enough spaces to accommodate the bulkier intermediates of V DFBP and 1 V´. This pore confinement cause Au@HMiPNs(TBB) and Au@HMePNs(TBPB) to produce the desired 1a via the intermediates 1 V in the chemoselectivities of 95.9 % and 94.7 %, respectively. As the pore size further increases, Au@HMePNs(TBPBext) with a pore size centered at 5.72 nm can provide larger free space to accommodate the bulkier intermediates of V DFBP and 1 V´. Then the chemoselectivities of DFBP and 1b are increased to 14.9 % and 25.9 %, respectively. Particularly, because the anchored PPh3AuOAc is mainly distributed in an aggregate state on the surface of HMiPNs (Fig.S18) and lacks the pore confinement imposed by the confined space, Au@HMiPNs displays the similar low chemoselectivities of 1a (41.5 %), DFBP (45.9 %), and 1b (12.6 %) as homogeneous PPh3AuOAc. Therefore, it is concluded that the pore size-dependent confinement is an effective method for achieving the high chemoselectivity of the desired 1a in the Au-catalyzed arylation of benzene with 4-FC6H4SiMe3. 3.6 High chemoselectivity with enhanced regioselectivity Besides the above-mentioned homocoupling of Ar2-SiMe3 and further heterocoupling of biaryl with Ar2-SiMe3, the heterocoupling of Ar1-H with Ar2-SiMe3 at different C-H bonds is another limiting factor for achieving a high selectivity of desired heterocoupling biaryl. In the direct arylation of toluene with 4-FC6H4SiMe3 (15 h), four products, including 4-floro-4´-methylbiphenyl (2a) and 4-floro-2´-methylbiphenyl (2a´) via heterocoupling, DFBP, and 2, 4-bis(4-florophenyl)toluene (2b) via further heterocoupling of 2a with 4-FC6H4SiMe3, are confirmed by GC and GC-MS (Fig.S27). As shown in Fig. 6a and listed in Table S4, three homogeneous catalysts, including PPh3AuOAc, PPh3AuCl, and PPh3AuOTs, afford the desired heterocopling 2a (30.045.0 %) (TON/TOF = 1642/1.12.8 h−1) together with 2a´ (8.015.0 %), DFBP (40.052.0 %), and 2b (012.5 %). The low regioselectivities and chemoselectivities cannot meet the requirement for the highly selective synthesis of biaryls (Ar1-Ar2). The similar low regioselectivities and chemoselectivity are also observed for Au@HCPs-PPh3 [58] with non-uniform apertures (2a: 28.2 % (TON/TOF = 196/13.0 h−1), 2a´: 5.8 %, DFBP: 57.0 %, and 2b:9.0 %) and for Au@HMiPNs with small micropores (2a: 47.4 % (TON/TOF = 116/7.7 h−1), 2a´: 9.7 %, DFBP: 40.3 %, 2b: 2.6 %) (Fig.S32). Fortunately, both Au@HMiPNs(TBB) (Fig.S29) and Au@HMePNs(TBPB) (Fig.S30) promote the reactions to afford 2a in the excellent selectivities of 94.8 % and 97.1 % with the high TON/TOF of 805/53.7 h−1 and 933/62.2 h−1, because the pore confinement can prevent the formations of the bulkier intermediates of V DFBP and 2 V´, producing DFBP in very low selectivities (2.3 % and 1.8 %) and trace 2b, respectively. Furthermore, the regioselectivities of toluene at the ortho-position are improved from 8.015.0 % to below 3 %, indicating that the limited spaces of the cylindrical pores can effectively prevent the CH bond at the ortho-position of toluene from being activated by Au single-atom to form the intermediate 2 V o , due to the steric hindrance caused by the wall of the cylindrical pore. Upon further increasing the pore size to 5.72 nm, Au@HMePNs(TBPBext) can provide some larger spaces to accommodate the intermediates 2 V o , V DFBP and 2 V´, leading to a significantly decreased selectivity for 2a (79.2 %) with lower TON/TOF of 506/33.7 h−1 and increased selectivity for 2a´ (7.0 %), DFBP (13.7 %), and detectable 2b (0.1 %) (Fig.S31). Based on the conversion of FC6H4SiMe3, the selectivity of 2a, and TON and TOF, Au@HMePNs(TBPB) with pore sizes centered at 3.43 nm and 4.52 nm is considered to be the most suitable catalyst for achieving the high yield of the desired 2a (93.3 %). The more bulkier o-xylene is selected as Ar1-H to further investigate the pore size-dependent confinement for achieving a high selectivity of biaryls (Ar1-Ar2). As shown in Fig. 6b and listed Table S5 (15 h), homogeneous PPh3AuOAc shows a low regioselectivity (49.8 %) of 3a (TON/TOF = 8/0.3 h−1;) together with a low chemoselectivity (3a´: 9.1 %; DFBP: 37.8 %; 3b: 3.3 %). The surface catalysis enables Au@HMiPNs to promote the reaction in a similar low regioselectivity and chemoselectivity of 3a (40.3 %) as PPh3AuOAc (Fig.S38). In comparison with toluene, o-xylene affords the corresponding intermediates 3 V, 3 V o , and 3 V´ with larger volumes, especially in the widths. Au@HMiPNs(TBB) with the micropores centered at 0.93 nm cannot provide enough space to accommodate these intermediates, and produces 3a in a selectivity of only 9.7 % and DFBP in a high selectivity of 90.3 % (Fig.S35), indicating that the formation of the intermediate 3 V has a greater steric hindrance than that of the intermediate V DFBP . Owing to the enlarged pore size and high reactivity of o-xylene with 4-FC6H4Si(CH3)3, Au@HMePNs(TBPB) with the mesopores centered at 3.43 nm and 4.52 nm can provide the larger space to accommodate the intermediate 3 V, and promote the reaction (TON/TOF = 995/66.3 h−1) to afford 3a in an excellent selectivity (>99.5 %) (Fig.S36). Unfortunately, as the pore size further increases to 5.72 nm, the confinement of pore on the formations of the intermediates is sharply weakened, HMePNs(TPPBext)@Au produces the products in very low selectivities (3a: 35.3 %; 3a´: 33.9 %; DFBP: 30.8 %; trace 3b) (Fig.S37). In view of the conversion of FC6H4SiMe3 and the selectivity of 3a, Au@HMePNs(TBPB) with pore sizes centered at 3.43 nm and 4.52 nm is the most suitable catalyst for achieving the high yield of the desired 3a (>99 %). Overall, after Ph3PAuOAc is anchored to HMePNs, the intramolecular or intermolecular Au···Au interactions in the structural motif of homogeneous Ph3PAuOAc are significantly weakened [59]. The site isolation of Au single-atom and the high porosity (surface area: 1221.1 m2 g−1; pore volume: 1.32 cc g−1) with a uniform pore size (35 nm) enable Au@HMePNs(TBPB) to promote the oxidative direct arylations of benzene and substituted benzenes with FC6H4SiMe3 in significantly higher conversions than homogeneous Au catalysts. Moreover, the chemoselectivities and regioselectivities can be effectively modulated to the desired biphenyls (1a, 2a, and 3a) in high yields (>93 %) via the pore confinement by anchoring PPh3AuOAc to the confined pores of Au@HMePNs(TBPB). 3.7 Pore confinement loss of anchored Au The direct arylation of toluene with 4-FC6H4Si(CH3)3 is selected as a probe reaction to investigate the long-term catalytic performances of Au@HMePNs(TBPB). After the completion of the arylation, the catalyst is isolated by centrifugal separation, washed by CHCl3, and directly reused in the following catalytic cycles. It is found that the catalyst exhibits a good reusability without a significant decreases in the conversions of 4-FC6H4Si(CH3)3, yields and selectivities of 2a over twelve catalytic cycles with a total turnover number (TON = 1.18 × 105) (Table S7). In the twelfth recycle, the desired 2a is produced in 88.7 % yield with an excellent selectivity of 96.7 % and a conversion of 91.7 %, indicating that the catalyst has good reusability in catalytic performances. From N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig.S41) and TEM images (Fig.S40b), the catalyst can maintain its original morphology of hollow nanospheres and pore-abundant shell with a little decrease in surface area (1013.3 m2 g−1) and pore volume (1.09 cc g−1). AC-HAADF STEM image (Fig.S40e) indicates that the anchored PPh3AuOAc is well distributed in the pores as its fresh state of single-atoms (bright points). Moreover, ICP-OES shows that there is 5.1 % of Au loss from 0.88 to 0.84 mmol g−1 (Fig.S39b and Table S6). Therefore, it is confirmed that the slight loss of Au and a little decrease in surface area and pore volume are the main causes for the slightly reduced catalytic activity of the catalyst. Particularly, it is worth mentioning that the pores provide a confined environment to prevent the anchored PPh3AuOAc from escaping out from the pores and stabilize PPh3AuOAc species to avoid their self-assembly, depending on the pore sizes of the catalysts. It is found that the elution of the anchored Au in Au@HMiPNs(TBB) with the small pores decreases to 3.6 % over twelve catalytic cycles (Fig.S39a), and the Au single-atoms (bright points) are well kept (Fig.S40d). Unlike Au@HMiPNs(TBB) and Au@HMePNs(TBPB), Au@HMePNs(TPPBext) with the larger pores has a significantly increased elution (13.8 %) of the anchored PPh3AuOAc. After the accumulated reaction solutions containing lost Au species are dried, no catalytic activity of the residue is found in the reaction. Furthermore, the reaction mixture is monitored by 31P NMR, and no phosphorus peak is observed. It is conjectured that the anchored Ph3PAuOAc is released to the solvent through the dissociation of phosphine ligand (PPh3) with Au(I) to form gold acetate. Moreover, the AC-HAADF STEM image shows some anchored Au single-atoms are aggregated to the nanoparticles with a diameter of about 20 nm (Fig.S40f). Therefore, it is concluded that the weakened pore confinement of larger pores in Au@HMePNs(TPPBext) leads to the loss and aggregation of the anchored PPh3AuOAc single-atoms. 4 Conclusions This contribution develops the convenient and low-cost methods for fabricating hollow mesoporous/microporous polystyrene nanospheres with high porosity via the pillarings of cross-linkers and supported Au single-atom catalyst via the direct covalent linkage of Ph3PAuOAc. The supported Au single-atom catalysts possess the fascinating structural features including hollow interior, nanospherical morphology, thin and pore-abundant shell with controllable and uniform pores, and Au single-atom, which are well suited to the fast mass transfer of reactants and high catalytic activity of anchored Au in the oxidative direct arylation of arenes (Ar1-H) with arylsilane (Ar2-SiMe3). The controllable and uniform pores in HMPNs-supported Au catalyst provide spatial environments to afford the desired heterocoupling product in excellent chemoselectivities with improved regioselectivities by means of pore-dependent confinement. Moreover, the leaching and aggregation of anchored Au single-atoms are effectively suppressed, due to pore size-dependent confinement. The long-term catalytic performances indicate that Au@HMePNs(TBPB) possesses good stabilities in morphology, porous structure, Au single-atom, and leaching resistance of Au over twelve recycles with a record turnover number (TON = 1.18 × 105), highlighting its potential application in large-scale synthesis. Overall, this paper showcases a highly successful strategy for achieving highly selective synthesis of biaryls by means of pore-dependent confinement, which is difficult to be achieved with Au catalysts in homogeneous catalysis. coredata.dc:description: The Au-promoted direct arylation of simple arenes (Ar1-H) with arylsilanes (Ar2-SiMe3) to construct widely used biaryls (Ar1-Ar2) in high selectivities has an undoubted synthetic value but remains challenging. Herein, the direct covalent immobilization of Ph3PAuOAc to crosslinker-pillared hollow porous polystyrene nanospheres is developed via AlCl3-promoted Scholl reaction, affording supported Au catalysts with the fascinating structural features including nanosphere, hollow interior, pore-abundant shell with tunable pore size, and atomically dispersed Au. Fast mass transfer of reactant, pore size-depending selectivity, and highly active Au single-atom enable direct arylation to achieve high conversions (> 96.1 %) of 4-FC6H4SiMe3 with excellent selectivities (> 96.7 %) of hetero-coupling biphenyls, whereas homogeneous Au catalysts show unsatisfactory conversions with poor selectivities (< 49.8 %). The Au catalyst has a good reusability with a record turnover number (TON = 1.18 × 105) over twelve recycles. Overall, this paper showcases a success in achieving highly selective synthesis of biaryls originating from pore-dependent confinement.
coredata.dc:title: Pore size-dependent confinement: High selectivity promoted by pore-confined Au single-atom catalysts in direct arylation
